issues.text: Where an industrial dispute has been referred to a tribunal for adjudication by the appropriate government under s. 10(1)(d) of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947, can the said government supersede the said reference pending adjudication before the tribunal constituted for that purpose?

anchor.surface_text: GAJENDRAGADKAR J.-Where an industrial dispute has been referred to a tribunal for adjudication by the appropriate government under s. 10  1   d  of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947,  XIV of 1947 , can the said

issues.text: Does s. 21 of the General Clauses Act apply to the provisions of s. 10(1) of the Industrial Disputes Act so as to confer an implied power to cancel or supersede a reference?

anchor.surface_text: provisions of s. 21 of the General Clauses Act, 1897  X of 1897 . Section 21 provides that where, by any Central Act or Regulation, a. power to issue notifications, orders, rules or bye-laws is conferred, then that power includes a power, exercisable in the like manner and subject to the like sanction and conditions  if any , to add to, amend, vary or rescind any notifications, orders, rules or byelaws so issued . It is well settled that this section embodies a rule of construction and the question whether or not it applies to the provisions of a particular statute would depend on the subject-matter, context, and the effect,

issues.text: Is the power to cancel or supersede a reference under s. 10(1) of the Industrial Disputes Act implied in the scheme of the Act, independent of s. 21 of the General Clauses Act?

anchor.surface_text: of the relevant provision, of the said statute. In other words it would be necessary to examine carefully the scheme of the Act, its object and all its relevant and material provisions before deciding whether by the application of the rule of construction enunciated by s. 21, the appellants contention is justified that the power to cancel the reference made under s. 10 1  can be said to vest in the appropriate government by necessary implication. If we come to the conclusion that the context and -effect of the relevant provisions is repugnant to the application of the said rule of construction, the appellant would not be entitled to invoke the assistance of the said section. We must, therefore, proceed to examine the relevant provisions of the Act itself.

issues.text: If a dispute referred under s. 10(1) is settled by the parties pending adjudication, must the appropriate government cancel the reference to give effect to the settlement, or can the tribunal record it?

anchor.surface_text: companyresponding to the provisions of O. XXIII, r. 3 of the Code of Civil Procedure. But it would be very unreasonable to assume that the industrial tribunal would insist upon dealing with the dispute on the merits even after it is informed that the dispute has been amicably settled between the parties. We have already indicated that amicable settlements of industrial disputes which generally lead to industrial peace and harmony are the primary object of this Act.

anchor.surface_text: As we read the judgment, we are number inclined to accept the appellants assumption that the passage just cited expresses the view accepted by this court.

holdings.text: The appropriate government has no power to supersede or cancel a reference made under s. 10(1) of the Industrial Disputes Act pending adjudication before the tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: GAJENDRAGADKAR J.-Where an industrial dispute has been referred to a tribunal for adjudication by the appropriate government under s. 10  1   d  of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947,  XIV of 1947 , can the said

holdings.reasoning_summary: No express power; implied power via s.21 GCA inapplicable due to repugnancy with scheme vesting exclusive jurisdiction in tribunal post-reference; inconsistent with ss.10 proviso, 10(2), 12(5), 20(3), 33.

holdings.text: Section 21 of the General Clauses Act does not apply to s.10(1) of the ID Act as it is repugnant to the subject-matter, context and effect of the relevant provisions.

anchor.surface_text: provisions of s. 21 of the General Clauses Act, 1897  X of 1897 . Section 21 provides that where, by any Central Act or Regulation, a. power to issue notifications, orders, rules or bye-laws is conferred, then that power includes a power, exercisable in the like manner and subject to the like sanction and conditions  if any , to add to, amend, vary or rescind any notifications, orders, rules or byelaws so issued . It is well settled that this section embodies a rule of construction and the question whether or not it applies to the provisions of a particular statute would depend on the subject-matter, context, and the effect,

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.21 is mere rule of construction; does not apply where repugnant to scheme of ID Act which excludes govt intervention post-reference.

holdings.text: No implied power to cancel reference exists in the scheme of the Industrial Disputes Act independent of s.21 GCA.

anchor.surface_text: of the relevant provision, of the said statute. In other words it would be necessary to examine carefully the scheme of the Act, its object and all its relevant and material provisions before deciding whether by the application of the rule of construction enunciated by s. 21, the appellants contention is justified that the power to cancel the reference made under s. 10 1  can be said to vest in the appropriate government by necessary implication. If we come to the conclusion that the context and -effect of the relevant provisions is repugnant to the application of the said rule of construction, the appellant would not be entitled to invoke the assistance of the said section. We must, therefore, proceed to examine the relevant provisions of the Act itself.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Post-reference, tribunal seized per s.20(3); govt excluded except s.10(5); inconsistent with obligation to refer in certain cases and record reasons not to refer.

holdings.text: If parties settle dispute pending before tribunal, no need to cancel reference; tribunal can record settlement as award.

anchor.surface_text: companyresponding to the provisions of O. XXIII, r. 3 of the Code of Civil Procedure. But it would be very unreasonable to assume that the industrial tribunal would insist upon dealing with the dispute on the merits even after it is informed that the dispute has been amicably settled between the parties. We have already indicated that amicable settlements of industrial disputes which generally lead to industrial peace and harmony are the primary object of this Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Primary object industrial peace; unreasonable to force adjudication post-settlement; tribunals routinely make consent awards.

holdings.text: The notification issued by the government cancelling the earlier references is invalid and ultra vires.

anchor.surface_text: confirm the finding made by the learned judges of the High Court at Patna, that the notification issued by the appellant cancelling the first two notifications is invalid and ultra vires.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No legal power to cancel as held above; High Court finding confirmed.

holdings.text: Proceedings before tribunal commence immediately upon reference under s.10(1) and tribunal is seized of jurisdiction; government stands outside except under s.10(5).

anchor.surface_text: under s. 20 3  of the Act. This provision shows that after the dispute is referred to the tribunal, during the continuance of the reference proceedings, it is the tribunal which is seized of the dispute and which can exercise jurisdiction in respect of it. The appropriate government can act in respect of a reference pending adjudication before a tribunal only under s. 10 5  of the Act, which authorises it to add other parties

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of s.20(3) ID Act defining commencement and conclusion of proceedings.

holdings.text: Minerva Mills does not support implied power to cancel reference as no cancellation occurred; merely new tribunal after expiry.

anchor.surface_text: In the case of Minerva Mills Ltd.  1 , however, the question about the implied power of the appropriate government to cancel its order made under s. 10 did number arise...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinction: no s.10 order cancelled; first tribunal expired, new one appointed for pending references.

holdings.text: Strawboard Mfg. does not hold that government has implied power to cancel; observation was appellant's argument, not court's view.

anchor.surface_text: As we read the judgment, we are number inclined to accept the appellants assumption that the passage just cited expresses the view accepted by this companyrt.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Passage reflects counsel's submission, not ratio; no decision on cancellation power.

precedents.citation: Minerva Mills Ltd. v. Their Workmen 1 [1954 S.C.R. 465]

anchor.surface_text: For the appellant Dr. Bannerjee has strongly relied on the decision of this Court in Minerva Mills Ltd. v. Their Workmen  1 . He contends that Mahajan J. who delivered the judgment of the Court, has expressly observed in his judgment that from the relevant provisions of the Act It could not be held that it was implicit in s. 7 that the government could not withdraw a dispute referred to a tribunal or make the appointment of a tribunal for a limited period of time.

precedents.case_name: Minerva Mills Ltd. v. Their Workmen
precedents.cited_proposition: government has implied power to withdraw a dispute referred to a tribunal

precedents.citation: Strawboard Manufacturing Co. Ltd. v. Gutta Mill Workers Union 1 [1953 S.C.R. 439]

anchor.surface_text: The decision of this Court in Strawboard Manufacturing Co. Ltd. v. Gutta Mill Workers Union  1 , is then cited in support of the proposition that the appellant has implied power to cancel its order made, under s. 10 1 .

precedents.case_name: Strawboard Manufacturing Co. Ltd. v. Gutta Mill Workers Union
precedents.cited_proposition: State Government should have cancelled the previous notification and issued a fresh notification referring all issues

precedents.citation: The Textile Workers Union, Amritsar v. The State of Punjab and others 1 [A.I.R. 1957 Pun. 255]

anchor.surface_text: The third decision to which reference has been made in support of the appellants case is the decision of Bishan Narain J. in The Textile Workers Union, Amritsar v. The State of Punjab and others  1 . Bishan Narain J. appears to have taken the view that the power to cancel an order of reference made under s. 10 1  can be implied by invoking s. 21 of the General Clauses Act

precedents.case_name: The Textile Workers Union, Amritsar v. The State of Punjab and others
precedents.cited_proposition: appropriate government has power to cancel its order of reference under s. 10(1) invoking s. 21 General Clauses Act

precedents.citation: Iyyappen Mills Private Ltd., Trichur v. State of Travancore-Cochin 1 [1958 1 L.L.J. 50]

anchor.surface_text: The decision of the Kerala High Court in Iyyappen Mills  Private  Ltd., Trichur v. State of Travancore-Cochin  1 , is not of much assistance because in this case the learned judges appear to have taken the view that the first tribunal before which the industrial dispute was pending had ceased to exist at the material time

precedents.case_name: Iyyappen Mills Private Ltd., Trichur v. State of Travancore-Cochin
precedents.cited_proposition: government can refer dispute to second tribunal if first has ceased to exist

precedents.citation: Harendranath Bose v. Second Industrial Tribunal 3 [1958 11 L.L.J. 198]

anchor.surface_text: Then, in regard to the observations made by Sinha J. in Harendranath Bose v. Second Industrial Tribunal  3 , it is clear that the learned judge was in error in seeking to support his view that the appropriate government can cancel its order made under s. 10 1  by the observations found in the judgment of this Court in Strawboard Manufacturing Co. Ltd.  4

precedents.case_name: Harendranath Bose v. Second Industrial Tribunal
precedents.cited_proposition: appropriate government can cancel its order made under s. 10(1)

precedents.citation: South India Estate Labour Relations Organisation v. The State of Madras 5 [A.I.R. 1955 Mad. 45]

anchor.surface_text: The last case to which reference must be made is the decision of Rajamannar C. J. and Venkatarama Aiyar J. in South India Estate Labour Relations Organisation v. The State of Madras  5 . In this case the Madras Government had purported to amend the reference made by it under s. 10 of the Act and the validity of this amendment was challenged before the Court.

precedents.case_name: South India Estate Labour Relations Organisation v. The State of Madras
precedents.cited_proposition: government can amend a reference under s. 10 as it is mere technicality equivalent to independent reference

anchor.surface_text: We must, therefore, confirm the finding made by the learned judges of the High Court at Patna, that the notification issued by the appellant cancelling the first two notifications is invalid and ultra vires.

outcome.relief_summary: Confirmed High Court finding that government notification superseding earlier references is invalid and ultra vires

anchor.surface_text: provisions of s. 21 of the General Clauses Act, 1897  X of 1897 . Section 21 provides that where, by any Central Act or Regulation, a. power to issue notifications, orders, rules or bye-laws is conferred, then that power includes a power, exercisable in the like manner and subject to the like sanction and conditions  if any , to add to, amend, vary or rescind any notifications, orders, rules or byelaws so issued . It is well settled that this section embodies a rule of construction and the question whether or not it applies to the provisions of a particular statute would depend on the subject-matter, context, and the effect,

We must, therefore, confirm the finding made by the learned judges of the High Court at Patna, that the notification issued by the appellant cancelling the first two notifications is invalid and ultra vires.

edges.explanation: Holding of no implied power independent of s.21 GCA directly addresses the issue of power in ID Act scheme.

anchor.surface_text: of the relevant provision, of the said statute. In other words it would be necessary to examine carefully the scheme of the Act, its object and all its relevant and material provisions before deciding whether by the application of the rule of construction enunciated by s. 21, the appellants contention is justified that the power to cancel the reference made under s. 10 1  can be said to vest in the appropriate government by necessary implication. If we come to the conclusion that the context and -effect of the relevant provisions is repugnant to the application of the said rule of construction, the appellant would not be entitled to invoke the assistance of the said section. We must, therefore, proceed to examine the relevant provisions of the Act itself.

We must, therefore, confirm the finding made by the learned judges of the High Court at Patna, that the notification issued by the appellant cancelling the first two notifications is invalid and ultra vires.

anchor.surface_text: companyresponding to the provisions of O. XXIII, r. 3 of the Code of Civil Procedure. But it would be very unreasonable to assume that the industrial tribunal would insist upon dealing with the dispute on the merits even after it is informed that the dispute has been amicably settled between the parties. We have already indicated that amicable settlements of industrial disputes which generally lead to industrial peace and harmony are the primary object of this Act.

We must, therefore, confirm the finding made by the learned judges of the High Court at Patna, that the notification issued by the appellant cancelling the first two notifications is invalid and ultra vires.
